answers.answer: Yes, I can provide information on the types of illnesses that can be treated in a one day hospitalization. These include anemia, respiratory infections, urinary tract infections, viral or bacterial intestinal infections, infectious diarrhea, irritable bowel syndrome, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease, varicose veins without inflammation, acute tonsillitis, autoimmune thyroiditis, diabetes, ischemic cardiomyopathy, mitral or aortic valve insufficiency without indication for surgical intervention, and alcoholic hepatitis.

answers.answer: As per the given summary, starting from April 1, 2022, several types of medical treatments will be covered under the agreement between health insurance companies and public hospitals. These include chemotherapy services with monitoring provided in the day hospitalization regime, dialysis services provided in the health facilities running the National Program for the replacement of renal function in patients with chronic renal failure, and radiotherapy services provided by the health units that run the Radiotherapy Subprogram for patients with oncological diseases.

answers.answer: The purpose of requiring private hospitals to charge personal contributions is to cover the difference between the rates charged by the private hospital and those settled by the health insurance company, ensuring transparency and respecting patients' rights. This allows patients to have more control over their healthcare costs and makes them aware of what they should expect to pay before receiving hospitalization services.

answers.answer: No, if the doctor in the ward where the patient is hospitalized recommends, based on medical documents, certain medicines, sanitary materials or laboratory investigations, and the expenses for these are borne by the patient, even though he would have been entitled to benefit from them for free, the hospital will reimburse the patient the value of these expenses at the request of the insured.
